facts.text: On 14/17 March 1969, Government of Haryana issued notification under s.4 of the Land Acquisition Act notifying acquisition of land concerned and directing action under s.17(2)(c) on ground of urgency, provisions of s.5A not to apply.

Preamble to s.4 notification stated land likely required at public expense for public purpose: setting up factory for manufacture of China-ware and Porcelain ware including Wall Glazed Tiles etc. at village Kasser, Tehsil Jhajjar, District Rohtak.
On March 18, 1969, Government issued notification under s.6 acquiring the land for public purpose.
On March 28, 1969, notices under s.9 served on appellants.
On April 8, 1969, appellants filed writ petition in Punjab and Haryana High Court challenging proceedings under ss.4,6,9,17(2)(c).

Writ petition alleged no urgency justifying s.17 and deprivation of s.5A; acquisition for benefit of company requiring ss.38-44B; no public purpose; land not waste or arable land, s.17(2)(c) inapplicable.

Counter-affidavit by Deputy Director of Industries Administration, Haryana denied allegations; stated GOI issued letter of intent to company for factory at Kasser with collaboration of Pilkington Tiles Ltd.; scheme finalised and approved November 26, 1968; Government wrote to promoter Shri H.L. Somany to complete arrangements for import and land acquisition by April 30, 1969; urgency necessitated s.17.
State Government contributed Rs.100/- towards cost of acquisition, as mentioned in award of Land Acquisition Officer.
High Court dismissed writ petition on May 7, 1969; appeal to Supreme Court by certificate.
Appellant denied entire land was waste or arable; contention not examined by High Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether acquisition for a company required proceedings under ss.38 to 44B of the Act, rendering proceedings void.
Whether there was urgency justifying recourse to s.17 of the Act.
Whether s.17(2)(c) applicable to facts of case.

petitioner_arguments.text: Acquisition for company, proceedings should have been under ss.38-44B.
No urgency, recourse to s.17 unjustified depriving s.5A benefit.
Land not waste or arable; s.17(2)(c) inapplicable; urged ejusdem generis to limit s.17(2)(c) like ss.17(2)(a),(b).

respondent_arguments.text: Acquisition at public expense for public purpose of setting up industry; declaration conclusive unless mala fide.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.6(3), Land Acquisition Act; Somavanti v. State of Punjab

respondent_arguments.text: Urgency due to project deadline April 30, 1969; GOI letter of intent, collaboration with foreign company.
State contributed Rs.100/-, not purely for company under Part VII.
Facts within s.17(2)(c); not limited by ejusdem generis.

court_reasoning.text: Starting new industry in public interest, especially in industrially backward Haryana to tackle unemployment; Government decision on public purpose not challengeable unless collateral purpose; s.6(3) conclusive.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Purpose public; declaration not open to challenge.

court_reasoning.text: State contributed Rs.100/-; not necessary to proceed under Part VII.
Urgency existed due to project completion deadline April 30, 1969; prior lethargy irrelevant; Government's conclusion entitled to weight.

Proceed assuming not waste/arable so not under s.17(1); s.17(2)(c) applies as land for public purpose of urgent importance; no ejusdem generis as cls.(a),(b),(c) have different authorities, conditions, no common genus.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.17(2)(c) plain, broad scope; ejusdem generis inapplicable.

holdings.text: Acquisition for public purpose; declaration under s.6(3) conclusive absent mala fides.
State contribution meant no need for Part VII proceedings.
s.17(2)(c) applicable without ejusdem generis limitation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Smt. Somavanti v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Declaration of public purpose conclusive; Part VII not applicable if state contributes.

precedents_cited.case_name: Raja Anand Brahma Shah v. State of U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Court cannot go behind government declaration of public purpose absent mala fides.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. Ali Gulshan
precedents_cited.relevance: Ejusdem generis requires distinct genus; general words full meaning unless restrictive.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lilavati Bai v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Ejusdem generis only if context requires restricted meaning.

precedents_cited.case_name: K.K. Kochuni v. State of Madras and Kerala

statutes_cited.name: Land Acquisition Act, 1894 (as amended by Punjab Legislature)
statutes_cited.relevance: Governed acquisition proceedings; s.17(2)(c) permitted bypassing s.5A for urgent public purpose.

statutes_cited.name: Co-operative Societies Act, 1912
statutes_cited.relevance: Mentioned in explanation to s.17(1) for godowns.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed as none of contentions acceptable; High Court order upheld validating land acquisition proceedings under ss.4,6,9,17(2)(c).

key_quotes.text: So long as it is not established that the acquisition is sought to be made for some collateral purpose, the declaration of the Government that it is made for a public purpose is not open to challenge.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Confirms conclusiveness of public purpose declaration under s.6(3).

key_quotes.text: The conclusion of the Government in a given case that there was urgency [is] entitled to weight, if not conclusive.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: There is no basis to say that the general words in cl.(c) follow the particular and specific words in cls.(a) and (b). Nor can it be said that the specific words contained in cls.(a) and (b) constitute a category, class or genus.
key_quotes.speaker: court
